super_gui¶

G U I P l o t t i n g

Run this GUI interactively to look at your results. Project: SuperPlot. Author: Andrew Fowlie, KBFI, Tallinn. Version: 1.1.

super_gui.open_file_gui()[source]¶

GUI for opening a file with a file browser.

Return: filename – Name of file selected with GUI.

super_gui.save_file_gui()[source]¶

GUI for saving a file with a file browser.

Return: filename – Name of file selected with GUI.

statslib¶

statslib.point.best_fit(chisq, param)[source]¶

Calculate the best-fit.

Arguments: chisq – Data column of chi-squared. param – Data column of parameter.

Returns: bestfit – The best-fit point.

statslib.point.p_value(chisq, dof)[source]¶

Calculate the pvalue.

Arguments: chisq – Data column of chi-squared. dof – Number of degrees of freedom.

Returns: pvalue – A p-value for the given chisq, dof.

statslib.point.posterior_mean(posterior, param)[source]¶

Calculate the posterior mean.

Arguments: posterior – Data column of posterior weight. param – Data column of parameter.

Returns: postmean - The posterior mean.

statslib.point.shift(bin_number, nbins)[source]¶

Modify bin numbers so that bin numbers, initially (0, nbins + 1) because numpy uses extra bins for outliers, match array indices (0, nbins - 1).

Parameters:
  • bin_number (integer) – A bin number
  • nbins (integer) – Total number of bins
Returns:

Shifted bin number
Return type:

integer

One Dimensional Statistical Functions¶

This module contains all the functions for analysing a chain (*.txt file) and calculating the 1D stats for a particular variable.

statslib.one_dim.conf_interval(chi_sq, bin_centers, alpha)[source]¶

Calculate one dimensional confidence interval.

Warning

Confidence intervals are are not contiguous. We have to specify whether each bin is inside or outside of a confidence interval.

Parameters:
  • chi_sq (numpy.ndarray) – Data column of profiled chi-squared
  • bin_centers (numpy.ndarray) – Data column of parameter at bin centers
  • alpha (float) – Probability level
Returns:

Confidence interval.
Return type:

numpy.ndarray
statslib.one_dim.credible_region(pdf, bin_centers, alpha, region)[source]¶

Calculate one-dimensional credible region. Find \(a\) such that

\[\int_{-\infinty}^{a} p(x) dx = 1 - \alpha / 2\]
Parameters:
  • pdf (numpy.ndarray) – Data column of marginalised posterior PDF
  • bin_centers (numpy.ndarray) – Data column of parameter at bin centers
  • alpha (float) – Probability level
  • region (string) – Interval - must be “upper” or “lower”
Returns:

Bin center of edge of credible region.
Return type:

float
statslib.one_dim.posterior_pdf(parameter, posterior, nbins=50, bin_limits=None)[source]¶

Weighted histogram of data for posterior PDF.

Parameters:
  • parameter (numpy.ndarray) – Data column of parameter of interest
  • posterior (numpy.ndarray) – Data column of posterior weight, same length as data
  • nbins (integer) – Number of bins for histogram
  • bin_limits (list [[xmin,xmax],[ymin,ymax]]) – Bin limits for histogram
Returns:

Posterior pdf and centers of bins for probability distribution.
Return type:

named tuple (pdf: numpy.ndarray, bin_centers: numpy.ndarray)
statslib.one_dim.prof_data(parameter, chi_sq, nbins=50, bin_limits=None)[source]¶

Maximizes the likelihood in each bin to obtain the profile likelihood and profile chi-squared.

Warning

Outliers sometimes mess up bins. So you might want to specify the bin ranges.

Warning

Profile likelihood is normalized such that maximum value is one.

Parameters:
  • parameter (numpy.ndarray) – Data column of parameter of interest
  • chi_sq (numpy.ndarray) – Data column of chi-squared, same length as data
  • nbins (integer) – Number of bins for histogram
  • bin_limits (list [[xmin,xmax],[ymin,ymax]]) – Bin limits for histogram
Returns:

Profile chi squared, profile likelihood, and bin centers.
Return type:

named tuple (prof_chi_sq: numpy.ndarray, prof_like: numpy.ndarray, bin_centers: numpy.ndarray)

Two Dimensional Statistical Functions¶

This module contains all the functions for analysing a chain (*.txt file) and calculating the 2D stats for a particular pair of variables.

statslib.two_dim.critical_density(pdf, alpha)[source]¶

Calculate “critical density” from marginalised pdf.

Credible regions are the smallest regions that contain a given fraction of the total posterior PDF. This is in fact the “densest” region of the posterior PDF. There is, therefore, a “critical density” of posterior PDF, above which a point is inside a credible region. I.e. this function returns \(p_\text{critical}\) such that

math::
int_{p > p_text{critical}} p(x, y) dx dy = 1. - alpha

The critical density is used to calculate two-dimensional credible regions.

Warning

One-dimensional credible regions do not use a critical density.

Warning

The critical density is not invariant under reparameterisations.

Warning

Critical density is normalized such that integrated posterior PDF equals 1.

Parameters:
  • pdf (numpy.ndarray) – Marginalised two-dimensional posterior PDF
  • alpha (Float) – Credible region contains \(1 - \alpha\) of probability
Returns:

Critical density for probability alpha
Return type:

Float
statslib.two_dim.critical_prof_like(alpha)[source]¶

Use confidence levels to calculate \(\Delta \mathcal{L}\)

This is used to plot two dimensional confidence intervals.

Parameters:alpha – Confidence level desired

Returns: critical_prof_like

** TODO goodify comment **

Histograms the chosen parameters to obtain two-dimensional PDF.

Parameters:
  • paramx – Data column of parameter x.
  • paramy – Data column of parameter y.
  • posterior – Data column of posterior weight.
  • nbins – Number of bins for histogram.
  • bin_limits – Bin limits for histogram.

Returns named tuple: pdf, centerx, centery ** TODO goodify **

Maximizes the chi_squared to obtain two-dimensional profile likelihood.

Parameters:

  • paramy – Data column of parameter y.
  • chi_sq – Data column of chi_sq.
  • nbins – Number of bins for histogram.
  • bin_limits – Bin limits for histogram.

plotlib¶

Abstract base classes for plots.

class plotlib.base.OneDimPlot(data, plot_options)[source]¶

Base class for one dimensional plot types.

class plotlib.base.Plot(data, plot_options)[source]¶

Base class for all plot types. Specifies interface for creating a plot object, and getting the figure associated with it. Does any common preprocessing / init (IE log scaling).

figure()[source]¶

Return the pyplot figure associated with this plot

class plotlib.base.TwoDimPlot(data, plot_options)[source]¶

Base class for two dimensional plot types (plus the 3D scatter plot which is an honorary two dimensional plot for now).

plotlib.plot_mod.appearance()[source]¶

Specify the plot’s appearance, with e.g. font types etc. from an mplstyle file.

plotlib.plot_mod.legend(title=None)[source]¶

Turn on the legend.

Warning

Legend properties specfied in by mplstyle, but could be overridden here.

Parameters:title (string) – Title of legend
plotlib.plot_mod.plot_band(x_data, y_data, width, ax, scheme)[source]¶

Plot a band around a line.

This is typically for a theoretical error. Vary x by +/- width and find the variation in y. Fill between these largest and smallest y for a given x.

Arguments: :param x_data: x-data to be plotted :param y_data: y-data to be plotted :param width: Width of band - it is this width on the left and right hand-side :param ax: An axis object to plot the band on

plotlib.plot_mod.plot_contour(data, levels, scheme, bin_limits)[source]¶

Make unfilled contours for a plot.

Parameters:
  • xdata – x-axis data
  • ydata – y-axis data
  • data – Data to be contoured
  • levels – Levels at which to draw contours
  • scheme – Object containing appearance options, colours etc
  • bin_limits – Bin limits
plotlib.plot_mod.plot_data(x, y, scheme)[source]¶

Plot a point with a particular color scheme.

Parameters:
  • x – Data to be plotted on x-axis
  • y – Data to be plotted on y-axis
  • scheme – Object containing plot options
plotlib.plot_mod.plot_filled_contour(xdata, ydata, data, levels, scheme, bin_limits)[source]¶

Make filled contours for a plot.

Parameters:
  • xdata – x-axis data
  • ydata – y-axis data
  • data – Data to be contoured
  • levels – Levels at which to draw contours
  • names – Labels for the contour levels
  • scheme – Object containing appearance options, colours etc
  • bin_limits – Bin limits
plotlib.plot_mod.plot_image(data, bin_limits, plot_limits, scheme)[source]¶

Plot data as an image.

Warning

Interpolating perhaps misleads. If you don’t want it set interpolation=’nearest’.

Parameters:
  • data – x-, y- and z-data
  • bin_limits – Bin limits
  • plot_limits – Plot limits
  • scheme – Object containing appearance options, colours etc

Plot axis labels.

Parameters:
  • xlabel – Label for x-axis
  • ylabel – Label for y-axis
  • plot_title – Title appearing above plot
plotlib.plot_mod.plot_limits(ax, limits=None)[source]¶

If specified plot limits, set them.

Parameters:
  • ax – Axis object
  • plot_limits – Array of plot limits in order xmin, xmax, ymin, ymax
plotlib.plot_mod.plot_ticks(xticks, yticks, ax)[source]¶

Set the numbers of ticks on the axis.

Parameters:
  • ax – Axis object
  • xticks – Number of required major x ticks
  • yticks – Number of required major y ticks

Implementation of plot classes. These inherit from the classes in plotlib.Base and must specify a figure() method which returns a matplotlib figure object.

Plots should also have a “description” attribute with a one line description of the type of plot.

A list of implemented plot classes is at the bottom of this module. This is useful for the GUI, which needs to enumerate the available plots. So if a new plot type is implemented, it should be added to this list.

Also includes a function to save the current plot.

class plotlib.plots.OneDimChiSq(data, plot_options)[source]¶

Makes a one dimensional plot, showing delta-chisq only, and excluded regions.

class plotlib.plots.OneDimStandard(data, plot_options)[source]¶

Makes a one dimensional plot, showing profile likelihood, marginalised posterior, and statistics.

class plotlib.plots.Scatter(data, plot_options)[source]¶

Makes a three dimensional scatter plot, showing best-fit and posterior mean and credible regions and confidence intervals. The scattered points are coloured by the zdata.

class plotlib.plots.TwoDimPlotFilledPDF(data, plot_options)[source]¶

Makes a two dimensional plot with filled credible regions only, showing best-fit and posterior mean.

class plotlib.plots.TwoDimPlotFilledPL(data, plot_options)[source]¶

Makes a two dimensional plot with filled confidence intervals only, showing best-fit and posterior mean.

class plotlib.plots.TwoDimPlotPDF(data, plot_options)[source]¶

Makes a two dimensional marginalised posterior plot, showing best-fit and posterior mean and credible regions.

class plotlib.plots.TwoDimPlotPL(data, plot_options)[source]¶

Makes a two dimensional profile likelihood plot, showing best-fit and posterior mean and confidence intervals.

plotlib.plots.save_plot(name)[source]¶

Save a plot with a descriptive name.

Warning

Figure properties specfied in by mplstyle, but could be overridden here.

Parameters:name (string) – Prefix of filename, without extension

data_loader¶

data_loader.label_chain(data, info)[source]¶

Match labels to the data. i) Check if labels match data. ii) If they don’t, use data indicies.

Arguments: data – Data chain, to match arguments with. info – Loaded contents of info file

Return: label – Dictonary of labels, indexed with the same indicies as the data chain.

data_loader.load(infofile, datafile)[source]¶

Import the data used by SuperPlot.

Arguments: datafile - Name of chain file infofile - Name of info file

Returns: label – Dictionary with chain’s labels. data – Dictionary with chain.

data_loader.open_chain(filename)[source]¶

Open a text file or serialised data. If opening a text file, serialise data for future plots.

Arguments: filename – Name of chain file.

Returns: data – Dictionary of chain indexed with integers.

data_loader.open_data_file(filename)[source]¶

Open a text file and return dictonary of numpy arrays of data.

Arguments: filename – Name of chain file.

Returns: data – Dictionary of chain indexed with integers.

data_loader.read_info(filename)[source]¶

Read labels from a SuperBayeS style info file.

plot_options¶

A named tuple to represent the plot options as selected in the UI. Also loads default values from config.yml and makes them available.

TODO: This module should also do a reasonable amount of validation
of config variables.
plot_options.default(option)[source]¶

Retrieve the default value of a plot option.

Arguments: option - the name of the option

Returns: - default value of option

If no default is available, prints an error message and raises a KeyError.
